name: Mosapramine
summary: An atypical antipsychotic used primarily in Japan for the treatment of schizophrenia.
description: Mosapramine is a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic with antagonistic activity at dopamine D2, D3, and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors. It is primarily prescribed in Japan for schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders. It has a pharmacological profile similar to other atypicals but retains relatively strong dopamine antagonism, which can lead to extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) at higher doses.

sections.text: Antagonizes dopamine D2 and D3 receptors and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors, modulating dopaminergic and serotonergic neurotransmission.

adult.titrate: Increase gradually every few days as tolerated

sections.geriatric: Initiate at lower doses; monitor closely for side effects
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; lower doses may be required
sections.renal_impairment: Use with caution; monitor for adverse effects

sections.text: Improvement in psychotic symptoms may be observed within 1–2 weeks, with full effects in 4–6 weeks.

sections.black_box: Increased mortality in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs.
other: Monitor for metabolic changes including weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia
Avoid abrupt discontinuation to reduce withdrawal risk

sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in breast milk; avoid if possible

sections.text: Gradually taper over weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms or rebound psychosis.

items: May have slightly lower metabolic risk than some other atypicals, but monitoring is still necessary
